I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The project will support rehabilitation and modernization of the irrigation and drainage 
networks serving about 23,230 ha of land in the Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic (NAR) of 
Azerbaijan. The project will also help strengthen institutional capacity of the irrigation system 
management and operators. The project will include two indicative outputs: (i) irrigation and 
drainage infrastructure improved and/or constructed; and (ii) capacity of the State Amelioration 
and Water Management Committee (SAWMC) and water users associations in irrigation and 
project management improved. These outputs will result in the following outcome: irrigation and 
drainage system performance in NAR improved. The project will be aligned with the following 
impact: agriculture production and productivity increased as outlined in the strategic agriculture 
sector roadmap of the Government of Azerbaijan.1  
 
2.  The project is estimated to cost about $100.0 million, of which Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) is requested to finance $85.0 million through its ordinary capital resources in regular terms, 
or 85% of the total project cost; and the balance is expected to be contributed by the government. 
The  transaction  technical  assistance  (TA)  and  the  ensuing  loan  were  not  included  in  the 
Azerbaijan country operations business plan, 2020-2022, but will be included in the next country 
operations business plan for Azerbaijan.2 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The  transaction  TA  will  support  the  government  to  conduct  sector  and  capacity 
assessment, and to prepare feasibility studies and implementation startup for the ensuing project. 
These studies will include technical, environmental, social, gender, and economic and financial 
due diligence assessments. The feasibility study report for the entire project and advance design 
for the irrigation and drainage schemes for the first-year implementation will be prepared in 
accordance with the format and content that satisfy the requirements of ADB and the government 
in loan processing and approval. A TA grant of $1.2 million and about 18 person-months staff 
time will be required to prepare the ensuing loan project.3

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
5.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,335,000, of which $1,200,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). Key expenditure items 
are  listed  in  Appendix  1.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart staff, office space and access to internet, necessary data and information, facilitation

3 
of liaison with stakeholders during project preparation, and other in-kind contributions. The 
government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
6.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA.  ADB’s  Central  and  West  Asia  Department  will  select, 
supervise, and evaluate consultants. SAWMC will be the executing agency responsible for overall 
coordination and management of the TA implementation and provide necessary counterpart 
support to the TA consultants. SAWMC will establish a project management office to take care of 
daily administration of TA activities and preparation of ensuing investment project.  
 
7.  The overall TA implementation period will be about 22 months from February 2020 to 
December 2021. The TA consulting services will be implemented in two phases from May 2020 
to December 2021. The first phase, from May to August 2020, will (i) conduct rapid performance 
assessment of the current irrigation system and identify key weaknesses and constraints in the 
NAR; (ii) carry out hydrologic and hydraulic modelling to assess various water sources and 
whether remodeling of the canal networks is required; (iii) assess whether there is a need to 
increase pumping capacity and/or canal flow capacity; and (iv) recommend project scope for 
detailed feasibility studies. The second phase, from September 2020 to December 2021, will then 
conduct full-fledged feasibility studies for irrigation and drainage schemes identified in the first 
phase to meet both government and ADB requirements, advance design of the irrigation and 
drainage  schemes  for  the  first-year  implementation,  and  first  year  project  implementation 
preparation support.

Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.4 A consulting firm will be recruited to carry out project feasibility studies 
and advance design, and implementation start-up preparation through quality and cost-based 
selection method with quality and cost ratio of 90:10 using full technical proposals. During TA 
implementation, additional experts such as geographic information system specialist, structure 
design engineer, project management specialist may be required to meet emerging needs for the 
project feasibility studies and implementation start-up activities; and their selection will be carried 
out on individual basis. 
 
10.  ADB’s procurement. All Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and, the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as
